intro: Carex acuta var. chlorotica, commonly known as the green-tipped sedge, is a variant of the common sedge, Carex acuta, characterized by its distinctive greenish-tipped leaves. It is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetlands and marshy areas in North America. The plant produces cylindrical spikelets that contain small, wind-pollinated flowers. Its leaves are grass-like, typically narrow and slightly curved, with a dense, fibrous root system. It thrives in moist to wet soils and is often found in riparian zones and along the edges of ponds and lakes.
